div1.p:
Consulate to the United States
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887

Mr. Pratt
To the Department of State
Subject:
Claim of Dr. B. F. Wilson against King of Johanna
Abstract of Contents
Dr. B. F. Wilson's grievance and enclosing evidence bearing in case

Consulate of the United States
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887.

Honorable James D. Porter
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
I have the honor to address the Department at this time in relation to the claim of Dr. B. F. Wilson against Sultan Abdallah, King of Johanna.
This claim is of long standing and the Department has long since been made acquainted with particulars of the same.
Dr. Wilson now appeals again to the Government of the United States through the Department of State for some relief from the burden under which he is laboring.
To my own knowledge, he (Dr. Wilson) is virtually insolvent, and is consequently so pressed by his creditors in all sides as to be seriously hampered in the prosecution of his business.
By his nurturing and intelligent efforts he has developed his sugar plantation to such a state of of perfection as to make it (if unencumbered) a most desirable property.
But with its present debt it is quite impossible for him to work it to a profit.

There is no doubt that had the King of Johanna not taken the contemptible action he did to injure his prospects he (Dr. Wilson) would have been now in a position to realize large benefits from his imported Estate.

In
In September 1885. When Commander P. F. Harrington visited Johanna in the "Juniata", he made enquiry into the matter as far as was possible but it was very difficult to get any one to go on board the "Juniata" to testify against the King. Knowing that at the moment the vessel left they would be punished for so doing.
Dr. Wilson has when opportunity offered obtained what evidence he could bearing in his case: and I am sending the same herewith, as per the subjoined list of enclosures.

When Captain Potter was at Johanna in the "Lancaster" in April of last year he was inclined to take some action in the matter
matter. But the arrival of the French gunboat "Chaeal" in the harbor bearing the Commandant of Mayotte with instructions from his government to take over the Protectorate of the Island but a new phase in the affair and the "Lancaster" retired in good order.

It would appear that the King was coerced into signing the treaty with the French in account of the presence of an American man o'war in port from the fact that he afterwards protested against receiving the French resident who was finally landed by force in April of this year.

I am informed that the President has recently been negotiating a new treaty
treaty with the King but I have no idea what terms have been made.
From all that I have been able to learn, Dr. Wilson's actual losses by the King's interference cannot be less than $300,000.
Besides which he has been a sufferer from defamation of character and from attempts on his life.

Perhaps it would not be out of place for me to say here that I have yet to hear one word of derogation of his character in business methods. This among my acquaintances in Mauritius Réunion Madagascar and elsewhere

If this were not the case. I imagine that he would long since have been compelled
compelled to have retired from the field.
Trusting that the Department would give this matter the attention to which I believe it is entitled.

Sir,
Your Obedient Servant
Seth A. Pratt,

Johanna, 27th April 1886

Yes Doctor I remember very well that on the 20th inst, both to see the Commandant of Mayotte on his we have asked him, on behalf of the Captain of the U.S.S. "Lancaster", to be good enough to call in your Prince Mohammed, so the Commandant could ascertain that the letter received by Captain of "Lancaster" was not written by Mohammed, and consequently was a false document.
The Commandant of Mayotte, although you had upon him to get the truth ascertained, would give to you no other answer than, "let this matter drop: that is of no importance.

12th July 1886

B. F. Wilson Esqr M.D.
Johanna
Dear Sir

With to the scandalous reports which we have been maliciously circulated in on your moral character, we have pleasure in stating formally that having known you intimately for many years past both in business and privately we are in a position to declare solemnly and that all such are utterly without foundation and evidently spread with the object of you an injury

We remain Dear sir
Yours respectfully
(signed) Hendletta & Co. Merchants
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct copy of the original letter in file at this Consulate

Seth A. Pratt
U.S. Consul.

U.S. Consulate
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887

Oriental Bank Corporation in Liquidation
Mauritius, 18th July, 1886.

B. F. Wilson Esqr, M.D.
of Johanna.
Dear Sir,

Regarding your Claim against the King of Johanna for indemnity for the loss you have suffered through his interference with your labor supply during the past four years, we can say that we are well aware of the serious injury done to you and ourselves by the large reduction in the quantity of sugar produced by Patsy Estate resulting from that interference.

It is quite certain that had the Sultan not compelled a large number of your labourers to leave your employment with the object of crippling your operations, you would ere this time have been able to repay us the important advances of funds we made to you through Messrs Hondlette & Co. for the purpose of working your Estate. Your claim for indemnity is therefore clearly just and indisputable, and we trust the United States Government will enforce its payment as soon as possible.

With reference to the representations which we learn, have been made to your government by some evil disposed persons, reflecting on your moral character, we can only say they are false and malicious. During the last ten years we have been intimately acquainted with you: we have therefore had every opportunity of observing your behavior both here and in Johanna, and weare bound to
to say you have invariably conducted yourself as a gentleman of irreproachable character.

We remain, Dear Sir,
Yours Faithfully,
(Signed), For official Liquidator of the Oriental Bank Corporation
By His Attorneys
J. A. Ferguson
A. Wemyss

I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct copy of the original letter in a file this Consulate.
Seth A. Pratt
U.S. Consul

Domony, Johanna
May, 1887
Dear Doctor Wilson,

Having been requested to act as an expert in estimating the damage you suffered through the acts of Sultan Abdallah, and being personally acquainted with the affairs and also with the unwarranted conduct of Sultan Abdallah, toward you, I hereby state my opinion in the matter.

I know very well that the Sultan threatened your life by giving orders to his armed men to shoot you when they would get a chance of doing so; as you did not give them the opportunity, the plot failed, but it is nevertheless clear that the detention in your house through threats of being shot at, prevented you from attending to the work of your plantation, as well as to any other business you may have had in hand. I have seen also in your house several places where the boards had been cut through by bullets fired in the night and evidently intended for you. I know also of the scuttling and sinking of your steam launch while at her anchorage, and of the stealing of anchors and chains in your boat shed, all acts perpetuated by the Sultan's men and by his orders.

Regarding your labour, it is very well known to me and to every one in the island that in year 1883 the Sultan took away some hundred free men who were working for you, and gave orders to the Johannamen to withdraw from your employment any and all the slaves they had in it. This taking place while you were in full crop interfered not only with that crop, but with those that followed, as it prevented you from doing your planting and
and many other important works.

From the quantities of sugar you made during the preceding years, that is from 1879 to 1882 included, it is evident that during that period your crops were increasing by about one hundred tons every year. In the year 1883, time of the Sultan's interference, you made only half the quantities of sugar of the preceding year or three hundred tons less than you should have made had you not been interfered with by the Sultan.

The following years, 1884 to 1888, show a slight increase but not in a ratio with the first alluded to (1879-1882), and I should say that in those three last years (1884-1886) your yearly loss was as heavy as in 1883, or about three hundred tons yearly, making a total loss for the four years 1882-1886, of twelve hundred tons which, at the Mauritius market prices during these years would be worth, with interest, Rs. 300.000.

The above I consider to be as near as possible your losses from the Sultan's interference with your labour in 1883 & 1884, not speaking of the aforementioned attempts at your life, &c, and the general inconvenience you were put to by such unwarrantable acts.
Trusting that the U.S. Government will give to your case all the attention it deserves, and that you may some day be compensated for your losses,

I remain, Dear Doctor,
Very Sincerely Yours
(signed) A. B. d'Este
Manager of Pomony Estate, Johanna.
Mohilla, October 15th, 1887

Dr. Wilson M.D.
Patsy
Dear Sir,

In reply to your communication asking for any information known to me concerning your late troubles with the Sultan Abdallah and for which you are claiming an indemnity. I can state that your labour supply was almost entirely taken away from you leaving scarcely sufficient people to gather in your crop, thus neglecting all necessary work for future years, such as planting, hoeing, &c. Knowing as I do the progress made in yields during the first ten years cultivation of virgin land. I can assert that your loss must be have been enormous.

From the bullet holes I have seen in your house which were made by the Sultan's soldiers when passing through your estate I consider your life to have been in great danger. Indeed I know that it was so threaten that you had to exercise great caution even in moving round your house and entirely prevented from attending to your outside work. No one can entertain any doubt about your losses under such circumstances and I hope that your Government will give you
you the satisfaction you deserve, as I consider that you have been almost ruined
div1.ab:
With best wishes
I remain
Yours very sincerely
(signed) Robt. M. Dimley.

Mohilla, 12th Sept. 1885

To Dr B. F. Wilson,
Proprietor of Patsy Estate
Johanna
Dear Sir,

Having been compelled by force when imprisoned at Baumbau by Sultan Abdallah to make a false statement concerning you, I now wish to declare and publish that that statement was false. It was written by Sultan Abdallah for his own purpose and I was forced to sign it under penalty of death if I did not. The statement that he made me sign was that you had given me money to hire men to go and fight for Prince Mohammed and that you would pay ten dollars per head for slaves and fifty dollars for free men and in case a slave died or was killed you would pay fifty dollars to his master.

All this I now solemnly swear is false. I wish here to state also I have often heard Sultan Abdallah say that he intended to drive you away from Johanna and take your plantation for his own benefit and that of his own son Salim. I have heard him avow this intention many times previous to the outbreak of trouble between him and his brother Prince Mohammed since that occurred I was arrest and imprisoned on Baumbau because I sympathized with
with Prince Mohammed although I neither fought for him nor assisted him in any way whatsoever.

I remain, Dear Sir
Yours Faithfully
(Signed)
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct copy of the Original letter on file at this Consulate.

Seth A. Pratt
U.S. Consul

U.S. Consulate
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887
Mauritius 17th January, 1887.

Messrs Langlvis & Co.
Merchants.
Dear Sir,

As you requested when I went to Johanna on behalf of the Oriental Bank Corporation and the firm of Houndlette & Co to inspect and report upon the Sultan's sugar estate at Bambau I thoroughly inspected the estate "Patsy" belonging to Doctor Wilson. I found "Patsy" estate very well managed indeed, the canes well cultivated, and the plant of machinery in good order. I should judge that Dr. Wilson will this coming season turn out about 400 tons of sugar, and I see no reason why he should not go on increasing his production yearly, say from 75 to 100 tons until he makes 800 to 900 tons per annum. Dr. Wilson has done a great deal of hard and intellectual work at Patsy, and it is my opinion that had his labour supply not been interfered with by the Sultan since 1882 (when he made 527 tons of sugar) that he would have been making the 800 to 900 tons annunally since /84.

Doctor Wilson's losses from the cause above alluded to, I am sure cannot be less than one hundred thousand pounds sterling, taking into consideration the heavy fall in prices of sugar since that time, interest, &c &c, besides the loss of a certain quantity of canes abandoned and left in the ground, the latter taking from the soil the necessary properties for future cultivation of them.

The French Protectorate will I hope and trust work well for future operations as there is an abundance of labour on the island, and the men want to work, but as it appears were only deterred from doing so by the Sultan who evidently does not wish to see foreigners
foreigners succeed in his island. With the Protectorate he will not be allowed to interfere.
I do not consider that there is any risk whatever in making advances to Dr Wilson for working his estate.

I remain, Dear Sir,
Your Obedient Servant
(Signed) D. Dupont

Sworn and subscribed to before one this thirteenth day of June 1887.
Signed, Thomas T. Prentis
U. S. Consul,
Mauritius
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct copy of the Original letter on file at this Consulate.
Seth A. Pratt U.S. Consul.

U.S. Consulate
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887

I hereby certify that I was present when Dr Wilson made a settlement with Sultan Abdallah and heard Sultan Abdallah insist upon Dr Wilson's paying him interest for goods &c. that he had had from the Sultan from the date they were received until time of settlement, had heard Dr Wilson protest, but he had to give in to the Sultan in order to come to some settlement with him. It was well known that the Sultan had agreed to supply Dr Wilson with everything he required to make a plantation without charging him anything until his plantation was paying. This was offered him for the services he rendered to the Sultan Abdallah.

(signed) James Mitchell
Port Louis, Mauritius
6th, February 1884
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a current copy of the original statement on file at this consulate.

Seth A. Pratt,
U.S. Consul
Johanna, 25th April, 1886.

Dr B. F. Wilson has made 514 tons of sugar in 1882. At the commencement of the 1882 crop he was deprived of labour by Sultan Abdallah, so that he could not extend his plantation, and it has been invariably the same every year since that time (1882) so that instead of increasing his production of sugar yearly as he might have done had he had the required labour, it has fallen off, so that his last crop was only 227 tons; whereas he might have made, if not interfered with, 900 tons of sugar the last season: the estate being able to produce about 1500 tons of sugar, if all is put under cultivation.

It is a very easy matter for a crop to be largely reduced by want of labour during one season: but it is very difficult, and requires much time to increase it again. It will take Dr Wilson at least four years to get his production of sugar what it would have been had he not been interfered with.
I have had much experience on sugar plantations, being an agricultural chemist, and I consider myself well able to judge in this case, having spent the last twelve years in sugar colonies.

Another important consideration in connection with Dr Wilson's losses is the fall in the price of sugars for the last two years, which has been more than 30%; so even if Dr Wilson can produce the same quantity of sugar as he had been able to produce before, he could not get the same profit.

(signed) L. Ehrmann
Analytical Chemist
Fellon Chemical Society,
F.C.1. (London.)
Johanna, 25th April, 1886.

Ten days ago when the U.S.S. "Lancaster" was here, Captain Potter received from Sultan Abdallah a letter containing, I have been told so, false statements against Dr Wilson, and placing him under a very false position: this letter, bearing the signature of Prince Mohommed. When Dr Wilson knew this, he made some enquiries and learned positively that Prince Mohommed never wrote the letter referred to, nor any other letter to Captain Potter, but that this letter was written by a fellow S. J. Abdallah, by his orders, and falsely signed Mohommed. Having got this information, Dr Wilson asked Captain Potter to send an officer with the letter to Prince Mohammed to ascertain the fact. The "Lancaster" being ready to sail and under steam, no officer could go on shore, and Captain Potter referred Dr Wilson to the Commandant of Mayotte who was on shore making a treaty with S. Abdallah.
I was present when Dr Wilson asked the Commandant of Mayotte to call Prince Mohamed and make an enquiry on this letter falsely signed by him. Commandant of Mayotte declined to make any enquiry.
(signed) L. Ehrmanns.
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct copy of the original statement on file at this Consulate

Seth A. Pratt
U.S. Consul.

U.S. Consulate
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887
Mauritius, August 1st, 1886

I hereby certify that I was in Dr. Wilson's employ on Patsy Estate for six years, and I have heard Sultan Abdallah say on several occasions that he intended after Dr Wilson had got his estate in good working condition, to drive Dr. Wilson from the island, and get his estate away from him, and give it to his son Salim. He also promised to make me manager of the estate, if I would assist in getting Dr Wilson into difficulties. I am personally acquainted with Sultan Abdallah, and used to be very intimate with him. He commenced to try and deprive Dr Wilson of labour in 1882 and took away all his own slaves first from Dr. Wilson, and those of his Queen Boney Malala, about 50 in number. He requested them to leave Patsy without Dr Wilson's knowledge, and go to his garden at Jermanda He then tried to get all Johannamen to take their slaves from Dr Wilson's employ. At the same time he ordered all free labourers to leave, which they did, as they were afraid of the vengeance of the Sultan if they did not

(signed) L. Werber.
Subscribed and affirmed to this ninth day of August, 1886.

Zanzibar, November 10, 1887
Johanna 29 August, 1886.

I hereby certify that I was at Bambau and employed by Sultan Abdallah for the last five or six years, and I am witness to the bad statement that Sultan Abdallah has given to Johannamen because they were friendly to Dr Wilson and because they would not take their slaves away from his work when he ordered it, and swear to lies to injure him.
I have also often heard Sultan Abdallah say that he would drive Dr Wilson from the island, and take his plantation from him.

I was present also when his soldiers came and reported that they had sunk Dr. Wilson's steamer, and witnessed the great pleasure he expressed at the feat. The soldier that headed this last business was a slave of his by name Ramiela. I also know that the anchor stolen from Dr Wilson was done by Sultan Abdallah's orders and given to the Captain of his by the name of Moon Waley.
I was witness also at Sultan Abdallah sending the slave Maragook away, so he could not be a witness of Dr Wilson's.
I am also a witness that the report of is a correct statement.

Witness to signatures:
(signé) William Hill
" George Esson
" Cembo Mohamed Zaber.

Certifié exact, et les signatures Hill, Esson et Cembo Mohamed Zaber

Zanzibar, November 10, 1887.
Mayotte, September 26th, 1886.

I hereby certify that I was in the employ of Dr B. F. Wilson, proprietor of Patsy Estate when the Sultan Abdallah and his brother Mohamed were quarreling and fighting, and I was requested to leave the work of Dr Wilson with many others of his employees, but this I declined to do, when Sultan Abdallah sent an armed force to the estate of Dr Wilson and caused me to go to Baumbau, where I was beaten and chained in irons for sixteen days, and badly treated otherwise, because I would not swear to lies to injure Dr Wilson: but this I was at least obliged to do to save my life, and now, being free, I am glad to be able to speak the truth.

Sultan Abdallah has often said he intended to get Dr. Wilson into trouble and then drive him from the Island, so he could get his plantation for his son Salim. When Dr Wilson wente to the Sultan and requested him to send me back to the work, he wrote Dr Wilson that I refused to go. This is not true: I wished to go but he refused to allow me to. When the "Juniata" was in Johanna he told Captain Harrington that he had sent to Mayotte for one to come to Johanna as a witness: this is also not true; he never wrote to me at all.

These statements are facts.
(signed) Cobo Mohamed Zuban

Certifie exacte le signature ci-dessus
(signed) Le Resident de France
I hereby certify that the foregoing is a correct copy of the original statement on file at this Consulate.

Seth A Pratt
U.S. Consul

U.S. Consulate
Zanzibar, November 10, 1887.

I Drayman Abass do hereby solemnly swear and affirm that I acted as Prince Mohamed bin Sultan's agent in procuring arms and ammunition for him before the late rebellion in this island. I applied on several occasions to Dr Wilson for assistance which he invariably and firmly refused to give me. Saying he was on "" and would have nothing to do with the matter. I then heard of Mr. Delonza going to Zanzibar and employed him to execute the Commission for me. When the arms & ammunition arrived here I asked for Dr Wilson's permission to store them in his magazine. This he positively refused to grant me and they were in consequence carried on to Mayotte and horse Bi and when they came back here I had Prince Mohamed's boat ready to take delivery of the whole with the exception of a few packages which I put into a Mohd's boat.
I was authorized by Prince Mohamed to procure arms for him the best way I could as he considered his life to be in danger. Dr Wilson never gave me a single thing to assist Prince Mohamed with.

I knew he did not like the Sultan Abdallah for the reason of his having interfering with his labour supply and other things and I used every endeavor to induce him to aid me in carrying out my plans but without success. When Sultan Abdallah's soldiers attempted to take possession from Dr Wilson of a laden with Paddy I tried then to persuade him
persuade him to help me but he refused to .

I know that Dr Wilson possessed a few to arm his and Corporals with in case of trouble on his estate and I tried hard to get some of them from him but never succeeded in getting not even one to carry myself.
(Signed)

William Hill witness
(here also an Indian. signature)
